pageContext.title: Roadmap to a SaaS IPO: How to unicorn your way to $100m revenue
pageContext.content:
Nine years from garage to IPO

The world‚Äôs best entrepreneurs and investors have released highly valuable articles about SaaS startups. These readings contain a ton of numbers and metrics that are helpful to understand what a successful startup looks like at each step of the growth journey.

So, what happens if we put those numbers together in a spreadsheet? Can we paint the big picture of a SaaS startup from inception to IPO?

Here‚Äôs the result:

This article will walk you through the different steps that lead us to the chart above. Bear in mind that the numbers presented here are orders of magnitude rather than hard rules. They mostly apply to Silicon Valley-based and VC-backed SaaS startups. So, take them with a grain of salt. üôÇ

1. Timeframe: six years to unicorn, nine years to¬†IPO

Starting a startup is a long-term game.

Steve Blank, Morgan Brown, Brian Balfour, and Reid Hoffman have all described their own vision of the startup life cycle. Looking at it, we notice that a successful startup goes through three phases:

  • Garage‚Ää: going from problem to product-market fit
  • Growth machine‚Ää: expanding channels, product lines, and geographies
  • Unicorn‚Ää: stabilizing and becoming liquid (IPO or acquisition) above a US$1 billion market value

In 2016, the TTU (time-to-unicorn) was stable at six years in the US. A unicorn, as originally defined by Aileen Lee of Cowboy Ventures, is a tech company (public or private) that reaches US$1 billion in valuation. More recent definitions exclude public companies from the scope for obscure reasons. Regardless, joining the blessing of unicorns remains a big deal, if not the mark of success for most founders.

The Australian unicorn is Atlassian (developer tools), while the South American one is Decolor (hotel and flight booking). / Photo credit: Fleximize

What about IPOs, then? Data from Pitchbook suggest a median time of 8.2 years between the first VC funding and IPO. Throw in an extra 12 months of existence before the first funding round (purely speculative), and we are looking at a TTI (time-to-IPO) of nine years, give or take. So much for the quick buck!

A startup becomes a unicorn at US$100 million in revenue, then usually IPO a few years later.

2. Growth: triple twice, double thrice, then 82 percent growth persistence

In a 2015 article, Neeraj Agrawal suggested that SaaS growth follows a clear pattern.

First, you establish product-market fit either instantly or within up to two years. Second, you reach US$2 million in annual recurring revenue (ARR), which is another one to two years. From there on, things become pretty predictable, and Agrawal puts forward the T2D3 rule (i.e. revenue triples twice then doubles thrice in the next five years).

On this graph, you can see Salesforce kicking ass.

Bottom line: You should pass the US$100 million mark in ARR six to nine years after starting.

What about after that? According to Rory O‚ÄôDriscoll of Scale Venture Partner, ‚Äúfor a best-in-class SaaS company, the growth rate for any given year is [82] percent of the growth rate of that same company in the prior year.‚Äù

In a nutshell:

  • ARR: Product-market fit¬†‚Üí US$2 million¬†‚Üí US$6 million ‚Üí US$18 million¬†‚Üí US$36 million ‚Üí US$72 million ‚Üí US$144 million ‚Üí US$262 million ‚Üí US$438 million
  • Growth rate: 0 percent¬†‚Üí 200 percent ‚Üí 200 percent ‚Üí 100 percent ‚Üí 100 percent ‚Üí 100 percent ‚Üí 82 percent ‚Üí 67 percent

Revenue follows an S-curve: slow growth until product-market fit, fast growth until ~US$100 million in revenue, then slow growth again.

3. Profit at scale = 40 percent ‚Äì growth¬†rate

Now that the top line is clear, let‚Äôs look at the bottom line.

In the early days, it is safe to assume that the company grosses in little to no profit. Once you are above US$50 million ARR, however, things change.

In a 2015 article, Brad Feld formulates the 40 percent rule: your growth rate + your profit should add up to 40 percent.

Growing revenue or margins? That‚Äôs the question. / Photo credit: Pacific Crest Group

We will assume that you run your infrastructure in the cloud, so profit = EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization). But as Feld points out, reality may be more complex if you run your own infrastructure.

Once you hit ~US$50 million in revenue, your profit should be 40 percent minus growth rate.

4. Funding: seed, series A, series B

Fundraising also follows patterns. Based on Chris Janz‚Äôs world-famous napkin, a SaaS startup can expect to raise:

  • A seed round at US$0 to US$1 million ARR and 0 percent annual growth
  • A series A round at US$1 million to US$1.5 million ARR and 200 percent annual growth (x3).
  • A series B round at US$5 million ARR and 150 percent annual growth (x2.5).

This is a cropped version of the napkin, but you should absolutely see the full version‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs a classic.

Let‚Äôs assume that you raise funds every 18 months for seed, series A, and B. After that, things become blurry.

Janz also offers typical valuations and round sizes in his article, so you can easily assess whether your US$10 million ask for a seed round is realistic (hint: it‚Äôs probably not).

Typically, funding is structured in several rounds (seed, series A, B, C, etc). Then, it‚Äôs time to IPO.

5. Exit: sell at US$1 million or US$10 million ARR or IPO at US$100 million ARR

As your startup grows, you may be presented with opportunities to sell. Perhaps, a competitor with deeper pockets wants to clear up the space. Or perhaps a large corporation will see a ‚Äústrategic fit‚Äù with your team, product, and/or clients. Most of the time, it‚Äôs both.

These opportunities, however, are not equally distributed during the startup life cycle. According to Jason Lemkin, there are two local maxima for an acquisition:

  • At US$1 million ARR: when you are ‚Äúhot and cheap‚Äù
  • At US$10 million ARR (and decreasing until US$100 million): when you become meaningful but still affordable

Eyes on the prize!

So, if you feel like you won‚Äôt make it to the next milestone, it may make sense to sell at a local maximum. Or is there an alternative?

If you want to go big, you will want to IPO. But what makes a successful IPO? A successful SaaS IPO follows a line that O‚ÄôDriscoll calls the Mendoza Line, with ARR on the x-axis and forward growth rate on the y-axis.

Assuming that you maintain 82 percent of last year‚Äôs growth rate, every year

In short, this is what your metrics should look like before you go public:

  • US$100 million ARR
  • 25 percent forward growth rate

These numbers are incredibly hard to achieve, and that‚Äôs what the author calls ‚Äúthe realistic low bar to IPO.‚Äù Unsurprisingly, there have been only 21 tech IPOs per year over the last five years.

The best opportunities to exit in SaaS are at US$1 million ARR, US$10 million ARR, and after US$100million ARR.

To put it in perspective, let‚Äôs look at what it means in terms of sales.

6. Sales: US$100 million ARR = ARPA x number of customers

Our target is US$100 million ARR. Now, your ARPA (average revenue per account) is a constant by definition. So, you can derive the number of clients that you need following Janz‚Äô chart:

At US$10 million ARPA, you need 10 clients to IPO. At US$1 million ARPA, you need 100 clients to IPO. ‚Ä¶ At US$1 ARPA, you need 100 million clients to IPO.

I gave them names: Wally, Denver, Dumbo, Bambi, Roger, Mickey, Marty, and Dick.

Say you address a market of ‚Äúprosumers,‚Äù like Wix, Typeform, Evernote, or Mailchimp do. You charge on average US$100 per year per customer. Not only do you need 1 million paying customers to IPO, you also need to add 250,000 more customers next year (and/or upsell by as much).

To be a unicorn, you need 100 clients at US$1 million ARPA or 1 million clients at US$100 ARPA.

Still looks like something feasible? Then, let‚Äôs look at how many people it takes to build this kind of company.

7. Headcount: US$200,000 ARR per¬†employee

The headcount increases as you move forward through the startup life cycle.

Conveniently enough, Tom Tunguz from Redpoint has already done the math for us. In SaaS companies at scale, the average revenue per employee stands at US$200,000 (True, this is for 2012 and companies at scale. If you have better numbers, hit me up and I‚Äôll update them!)

Once again, Salesforce (ticker: CRM) is kicking ass.

***

At the end of the day, this is what our roadmap to a SaaS IPO looks like.

Keep in mind that this is ‚Äúunicorning your way to US$100 million ARR,‚Äù meaning it‚Äôs the (supposedly) perfect trajectory. Obviously, it‚Äôs a super wide generalization. Not one startup will follow this roadmap strictly, and counterexamples abound. But frameworks are useful, and hopefully this one will be useful too.

This article was first published on Medium.

seo.title: Roadmap to a SaaS IPO: How to unicorn your way to $100m revenue
seo.description: We‚Äôve put together a ton of numbers and metrics together in a spreadsheet to paint the big picture of a SaaS startup from inception to IPO.
